author: protolambda
content:
<@!118185622543269890> Just some cases:
- memory loss due to shutdown: fire, power outage, system error, kill -9
- running the same key on multiple nodes that are not synced the same
- beacon node bug providing invalid info to validator (catch double/surround on validator side)
- running duplicate of the validator process
- duplicate validator entry with same key, run under same node as two by accident

TLDR: users and systems are fallible, try and be as robust and careful as possible

author: djrtwo
content:
IF the node follows the protocol (wrt fork choice and only updating justified/finalized to higher values) and the validator doesn't sign two messages in one epoch, then the validator would never do something slashable. 

But the "IF" on the node following the protocol is a major IF

author: djrtwo
content: (because of the things listed by proto and more)

author: djrtwo
content: So explicitly, the guarantees wrt "following the protocol" are more of a theoretical result and cannot be naively counted on

author: kiwi.eth
content:
I see! Thank you both. 
Most of what proto listed are "external" problems that can occur even if the validator client itself is not making any mistakes. Such as a user running a duplicate validator process. Is there anyway to protect a validator client from these?

author: djrtwo
content: Yes, the validator should never sign two attestations or blocks for the same epoch and should never sign an attestation at surrounds or is surrounded by a previously signed attestation

author: djrtwo
content: the validator should, independent of the node, be able to protect itself

author: djrtwo
content: even if the node is giving it crazy shit to sign

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**ajsutton**
Users are always going to be in trouble if they have their private key in two completely separate systems though. So running duplicate validator processes is going to be an issue you need to solve outside of the validator itself.

author: eth2_bridge_bot
content:
**ajsutton**
Mostly that boils down to restricting who and what systems have access to the private key very tightly.

author: djrtwo
content:
> Users are always going to be in trouble if they have their private key in two completely separate systems though

very true. having redundant nodes can make sense in many setups. Having redundant signing entities is extremely dangerous
